etymologies: Old English scild (noun), scildan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch schild and German Schild, from a base meaning ‘divide, separate’

definitions: a broad piece of metal or another suitable material, held by straps or a handle attached on one side, used as a protection against blows or missiles.
shortDefinitions: broad piece of metal or another suitable material, held by straps or handle attached on one side

definitions: a sporting trophy shaped like a shield, consisting of an engraved metal plate mounted on a piece of wood

examples.text: team captain Ben Hall collected the winners' shield

shortDefinitions: sporting trophy shaped like shield, consisting of engraved metal plate mounted on piece of wood

definitions: a stylized representation of a shield used for displaying a coat of arms.
shortDefinitions: stylized representation of shield used for displaying coat of arms

definitions: a person or thing providing protection

examples.text: a protective coating of grease provides a shield against abrasive dirt

definitions: a protective plate or screen on machinery or equipment

examples.text: a face shield is sometimes an integral part of a safety helmet

shortDefinitions: protective plate or screen on machinery or equipment

definitions: a device or material that prevents or reduces the emission of light or other radiation

examples.text: water is a relatively good shield against cosmic rays

shortDefinitions: device or material that prevents or reduces emission of light or other radiation

definitions: a hard flat or convex part of an animal, especially a shell

examples.text: the horseshoe crab's armor forms a huge domed shield

shortDefinitions: hard flat or convex part of animal

definitions: a large rigid area of the earth's crust, typically of Precambrian rock, which has been unaffected by later orogenic episodes, e.g. the Canadian Shield.
shortDefinitions: large rigid area of earth's crust

definitions: protect (someone or something) from a danger, risk, or unpleasant experience

examples.text: he pulled the cap lower to shield his eyes from the glare
these people have been completely shielded from economic forces

shortDefinitions: protect from danger, risk, or unpleasant experience

examples.text: the rocks she sat behind shielded her from the lodge

definitions: enclose or screen (a piece of machinery) to protect the user
shortDefinitions: enclose or screen piece of machinery to protect user

definitions: prevent or reduce the escape of sound, light, or other radiation from (something)

examples.text: uranium shutters shield the cobalt radioactive source

shortDefinitions: prevent or reduce escape of sound, light, or other radiation from

definitions: remain apart from others for a period of time in order to avoid catching an infectious disease to which one may be particularly vulnerable

examples.text: they are shielding to protect their own health
